coredata.dc:title: High-resolution soft x-ray excitation spectra of 3d-metal phthalocyanines
coredata.dc:creator: Koch, E.E.
Jugnet, Y.
Himpsel, F.J.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Sharp core-level excitons (1s → π*) are observed below the carbon 1s (289.5 eV) and nitrogen 1s (403.6 eV) threshold and broader features (1s → σ*) above threshold for metal-free and 3d-metal phthalocyanines (PCs). The fine structure of prominent sharp lines (white lines) originating from metal 2p → 3d, 4s transitions was resolved for MnPC at 640 cV to CuPC at 933 eV. The results demonstrate the excellent possibilities of high-resolution soft X-ray spectroscopy as a site-specific local probe of empty electronic states in complex organic compounds.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 116, number l CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 April 1985 HIGH-RESOLUTION SOFT X-RAY EXCITATION SPECTRA OF 3d-METAL PHTHALOCYANINES E E KOCH ', Y. JUGNET 2 and F.J. HIMPSEL IBM TJ. Watson Research Center, Box 218, Yorkto\vn Heights. NY 10598. USA Received 28 January 1985; in final form 8 February 1985 Sharp core-level excitons (Is -> IT*) are observed below ihe carbon Is (289 5 eV) and nitrogen Is (403 6 eV) threshold and broader features (Is -> o") above threshold for metal-free and 3d-melal phlhalocyanines(PCs) The fine structure of prominent sharp lines (white lines) originaling from metal 2p > 3d, 45 transi lions was resolved for Mn-PC at 640 cV to Cu-PC at 933 eV. The results demonstrate the excellent possibilities of high-resolution soft X-ray speclroscopy as a site-specific local probe of empty electronic states in complex organic compounds 1. Introduction The excitation of atomic inner shells by high-energy photons or electrons provides a method for investigat- ing unoccupied valence orbitais by making a transition from a well separated core level to a valence state [1]. This technique has the advantage to be site-specific due to the possibility to select different core-level edges of interest. In particular for organometallic com- pounds this technique has great potential for deter- mining the electronic states around active metal sites in a large low-Z-material matrix. Thus one can hope eventually to apply this technique to organometallic compounds of biological importance such as hemoglo- bin or chlorophyll. In the X-ray range where the metal Is absorption edges of the 3d metals are accessible, this idea has been tested and in a number of investigations the X-ray ab- sorption near edge structure (XANES) of organometal- lic compounds was studied [23]. The amount of in- formation is limited however due to two factors. First, the transitions from the Is level to the lowest unoccu- pied orbitais (3d, 4s) are dipole forbidden, and second 1 Permanent address. Fnlz-Haber-Inslitut der Max-Planck- Gesellschait, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Federal Republic of Germany. 2 Permanent address* Instatut de Recherches sur la Catalyse, CNRS, F-69626 Villeurbanne, France. 0 009-2614/85/S 03.30 Eisevier Science Publishers B. V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) the metal Is core levels are intrinsically broadened by lifetime effects and thus the resolution is poor. More recently the tuning range for X-rays has been extended to soft X-rays including the carbon, nitrogen and oxygen Is core levels. Furthermore the 3d-metal LJ( ]-[ edges (2p levels), which are the sharpest 3d- metal core levels, became accessible with sufficient resolution. In the present Letter we discuss the applica- tion of high-resolution soft X-ray excitation spectros- copy to organometallic compounds for the study of the unoccupied valence levels. For our studieswe have chosen the group of 3d-metal phthalocyanines (PCs) as model systems. Interest in the study of PCs is moti- vated by several aspects: first, their molecular structure (see the inserts in figs. I and 2) is very similar to that of chlorophyll and blood pigments. Thus they are good models for redox-active complexes in living or- ganisms or in catalysis. Second, molecular crystals of this class have interesting properties as semiconductors or for device applications [4]. The electronic structure of the occupied valence bands of the 3d-PCs and the binding energies of the core levels are well known from photoemission experiments [5]. Furthermore, the Li and L^ edges of transition metais exhibit prominent features due to transitions from the 2p^i^ and 2pi/2 levels to unoccupied 3d states. Thus it was hoped to obtain direct and otherwise inaccessible information concerning the empty 3d states. Volume 116, number l CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 Apnl 1985 2. Experimental details The experiments were performed with a new high- resolution 6 m/10 m toroidal grating monochromator which is described elsewhere [61. The samples were prepared by vacuum sublimation of PC powders on tantalum substrates. This was done partly in a separate evaporation unit and partly in situ- We measured the yield of photoelectrons above ;100 eV kinetic energy which is proportional to the absorption coefficient provided that the mean free path of the photoelectrons is small compared to the absorption length [7]. For the spectra shown as full lines in figs. 1 3 the energy resolution ranged from 0.2 eV at hv = 300 eV to about 1 eV at hv = 1000 eV. The dotted portions of the spectra were taken with a lower resolution. Although we were able to determine lineshapes with great accuracy, the absolute calibration of the photon energy could be off by 1 eV. 3. Results nd discussion In fig. 1 the excitation spectra for the carbon Is core to empty final-state transitions for Mn PC, Fe PC, Ni PC, Cu PC, and Zn PC are shown. For comparison the spectrum 0e metal-free H^ PC is also shown. All spectra are characterized by sharp core ex- citon bands labelled A, B, and C below or at the car- bon Is threshold at 289.5 0.2 eV and broader fea- tures in the continuum labeled D and E. The lineshapes and peak positions vary slightly within the series of metal PCs while the general appearance of the spectra is fairly similar. For some PCs peak A shows a clear fine structure with shoulders at the low-energy side. For the metal-free PC a significant shift ui the position of peak D is observed and E is absent. The C l s spectra of the PCs have great sunuanty with the benzene C Is excitation spectrum [8, ]. Thd latter is typical for ir-bonded unsaturated hydrocar- bons and shows a dominating Is ->- TT* resonance weaker sharp maxima in the discrete part of the spectrum and two broad resonances in the continuum. Thus in the PC spectra we assign the sharp peak. A at 285.3 eV to a l s -> Tr" transition with a tenn value of 3.7 eV. In analogy to the benzene spectrum the weaker features B and C at 287.2 and 289.1 eV respectively can be as- signed to Is - 3p and Is -> 4p core-to-Rydberg transi- 280 285 290 295 300 305 310 3)5 320 PHOTON ENERGY h ( eV 1 Fig. l. Carbon Is core-level excitation spectra for Sd-metal phthalocyanines and for Ha phthalocyaniae. The C l s ioniza- tion threshold at 289.5 0.2 eV foi phthalocyanines is given by the hatched marks. The insert shows the structure of a metal PC (full circles indicate N atoms). tions having mainly atomic 3p and 4p final-state char- acter- The broader peak D at 294.0 eV roughly S eV above threshold is due to a a-shape resonance. It cor- responds to the strong maximum in the benzene spec- trum, located at 293.5 eV [9]. Thus we have a I : 1 relationship between the main peaks in the benzene 1 spectrum and the spectra shown m fig. 1. The close similarity is not surprising, since there is a qualitative relationship between carbon carbon bond lengths and the location ofcr-shape resonances [10J, and most Volume 116, number l CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 April 1985 of the C C bond lengths m PCs are 1.37 1.38 A [11], very close to the C C bond length in benzene (1.40 A). Only the broad feature E at about 305 eV, which is absent in the H^ PC spectrum, has no coun- terpart in the benzene spectrum. The maximum at around 300 eV in the benzene spectrum is too far off in energy and hence it is tempting to ascribe this peak in the metal PC spectra to a a (carbon metal) reso- nance. Our view is supported by the observation of a broad and dominating resonance in the metal l s spectra of all 3d metal PCs 15 eV above the absorption thresh- 390 395 400 405 410 415 420 425 430 PHOTON ENERGY hr ( eV ) Fig. 2. Nitrogen Is core-level excitation spectra for 3d-metal phthalocyaninesand for H 2 phthalocyanine. The N Is ioniza- tion threshold at 403.6 0.2 eV for phthalocyanines is given by the hatched marks. The insert shows the structure of a metal PC (full circles indicate N atoms). old [12] which presumably has the sarne origin. The nitrogen Is core spectra are displayed in fig. 2. Again we observe strong and sharp core exciton lines (A, B, C) blow the N l s threshold at 403.6 0.2 eV [5] and broader features(D,E, F, G) m the continuum. Our explanation for the maxima A, B and C is similar to that for the C Is spectra. The maximum at 398.4 eV (peak A) with a term value of 5.1 eV is assigned as a Is - n* transition and the weaker peaks at 400.0 and 402.0 eV with term values 3.5 and 1.6 eV respec- tively are due to 3p and 4p atomic-type final states. For the assignment of the continuum features, we sug- gest also fairly localized final states. We note that the nitrogen Is spectrum in N3 also shows three maxima in the continuum from which the resonance 9 eV above threshold is assigned as a o- (N N) shape resonance METAL 2p ABSORPTION EDGE OF PHTHALOCYANBSES 1 8 ; 1 a MnPC | ^ 6S82 630 635 640 645 660 655 ^ 7139 f^n 7271. 695 700 705 710 715 720 725 730 735 MPC ^ ^ B776 845 850 855 860 865 870 875 880 B85 1 0 10507 1015 1020 1025 1030 1035 1040 l"4S 1050 1055 PHOTON ETeRSV h ( '.V l Fig. 3. Metal 2p core-levei excitation qiectra for 3d-wietal phthalocyanines. Foi Mn PC only ons of the spin orbit partners is shown. The hatched marks give the onization threshold energies as determined by XPS [5]. Volume 116, number l CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 April 1985 Table 1 One-election configurations in 2p-> 3d absorption for transition metals. A denote the atomic ground-state configuration, B denotes the configuration most probably realized in metal PCs. For the expected multiplet structure see fig. 4 Atom Transition l -* / + 1 Multiplet structure Transition / -* / 1 MnA B FeA B Ni A B Cu A, B ZnA.B 2p63ds4s2 2p6 3d6 4s1 - 2p6 3d6 4s2 - 2p6 3(1'^' -Zp^cr^s2- 2p63d94sl 2p63dl()4sl -2p63lllo4s^- 2p53d64s2 2p53d74s1 2ps3d74s2 2ps3d84sl 2ps3d94s2 2ps3dlo4sl case (a) case (b) case (b) case (c) case (d) singlet weak weak2p53d94s2 weale, case (d) 2ps3dlo4s2 singlet only continuum e(/ + l), e(/ - 1) transitions are possible [13] whereas the lower two features in the N^ spec- trum might have atomic N character (they are also visible in the NO spectrum). The most interesting experimental results are the metal 2p core-level excitation spectra (L^ 3 absorp- tion). They are displayed in fig. 3. Here we observe distinct changes within the 3d metal series from Mn to Cu PC. Finally for Zn PC only weak structureless absorption is observed at the 2p threshold, As known from other transition-metal compounds [14], the spin orbit interaction of the 2p hole is one order of magnitude larger than other terms. Therefore the spectra consist of two peaks split due to the spin- orbit interaction. Concentrating on the lower 2p3^ spin orbit partner, we note interesting changes within the series of spectra. A detailed analysis has to await configuration interaction calculations for the particular configurations involved. It is however possible to get a qualitative interpretation of the spectra by considering the possible one-electron transition (table 1). The result- ing most probable absorption spectra though for dif- ferent local symmetries and other ionic states have been calculated by Yamaguchi et al. [14]. These results are shown in rig. 4. In table 1 we have listed the atomic ground-state configurations as well as the electronic configurations most probably realized in the 3d-metal PCs [5]. Inspec- tion of table 1 immediately explains the absence of a sharp peak for Zn PC (no empty 3d and 4s states) and the sharp singlet line in Cu PC (only a single empty 4s state). For Ni PC where photoemission experiments suggest a 3d^4s^- ground state, we expect a strong 0505 RELATIVE ENERGY <eV) Fig. 4. Calculated La 3-absorpaon spectra for different final- state electron conf gUJat ons for 3d-metal compounds. A spec- tral resolution of JE = 1.0 eV was assumed for these calcula- tions (after r f. ( 14]). singlet line for the /- /+ 1 transition (empty 3d state) plus a weaker multiplet for the /-* / l transition (empty 4s state), which is consistent with the experiment observation. For Mn and Fe PC the comparison be- tween experiment and expected absorption lineshape leaves some ambiguity. Nevertheless, Zp^d7 (case b) and 2p53d8 (case c) final-state configura lions seem to be consistent with the observed lineshapes for Mn PC and Fe PC, respectively. Although a more detailed line- shape analysis must await multiplet calculations with the proper ligand field, we can already draw the con- clusion that the lineshape of the 2p core-level excita- tions is very sensitive to the occupation of the valence orbitais. 10 Volume 116, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 April 1985 Acknowledgement We wish to thank J.F. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Sharp core-level excitons (1s → π*) are observed below the carbon 1s (289.5 eV) and nitrogen 1s (403.6 eV) threshold and broader features (1s → σ*) above threshold for metal-free and 3d-metal phthalocyanines (PCs). The fine structure of prominent sharp lines (white lines) originating from metal 2p → 3d, 4s transitions was resolved for MnPC at 640 cV to CuPC at 933 eV. The results demonstrate the excellent possibilities of high-resolution soft X-ray spectroscopy as a site-specific local probe of empty electronic states in complex organic compounds.
